hints.content:
Let's visualize unrolling the ribbon by rotating the package.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: This diagram shows a ribbon being unravelled from around a cylinder in three stages. The first stage shows the cylinder fully wrapped, with a line coiling upward around the curved surface of the cylinder, making 3 full trips around from the bottom to the top. . In the second stage, the surface area from the line coiled around the curved surface of the cylinder down to its base has started to unravel from the bottom up into the shape of a triangle. The third stage shows the coil fully unravelled so that the cylinder has become a right triangle with height 'h', base (3 times (2 times pi times 'r')), and angle adjacent to the base of 30 degrees.

hints.content:
The sides opposite the $30^\circ$, $60^\circ$, and right angles of every $30^\circ$-$60^\circ$-$90^\circ$ triangle relate in a $1 : \sqrt{3} : 2$ ratio respectively.

[[☃ image 2]]

The length opposite the $30^\circ$ angle is $18\,\text{cm}$, and we want to know the length opposite the $60^\circ$ angle.  Let's use the variable $\ell$ to represent the length, in $\text{cm}$, of the ribbon.

>$\begin{align}
\dfrac{2}{1} &= \dfrac{\ell}{18} \\\\\\
\ell &= 36  \\\\\\
 \end{align}$

options.alt: This image shows a triangle with 30 degree, 60 degree, and 90 degree measures.  The side of the triangle opposite the 30 degree angle is labeled 's'.  The side opposite the right angle is labeled 2 's'.  The side opposite the 60 degree angle is labeled 's' square root of 3.

hints.content:
Alternately, we can use a trigonometric ratio to relate the angle of the ribbon, the height of the package, and the length of the ribbon. 

$\qquad\begin{align}
\sin(\theta^\circ)&=\dfrac{\text{length of opposite side}}{\text{length of hypotenuse}}\\\\\\
\sin(30^\circ)&=\dfrac{\text{height of package}}{\text{length of ribbon}}\\\\\\
\sin(30^\circ)&=\dfrac{18\,\text{cm}}{\ell}\\\\\\
\ell \cdot \sin(30^\circ)&=18\,\text{cm}\\\\\\
\ell &=\dfrac{18\,\text{cm}}{\sin(30^\circ)}\\\\\\
\ell &=36\,\text{cm}
\end{align}$

question.content:
Kapil wants to wrap a ribbon diagonally around a cylindrically shaped package, so that it makes $3$ full turns, then tape it at each end.  Note that the length of the ribbon can be represented by the hypotenuse of a right triangle by "unrolling" the spiral to a two-dimensional shape.  The package has a height of $18$ centimeters $(\text{cm})$, and the ribbon is at a constant $30^\circ$ angle relative to the lower edge of the cylinder.  About how long, in $\text{cm}$, does Kapil's ribbon need to be?
